entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6}, range 30/120 ft. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) Acid damage and the target has the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition ({@dice 3d10} Acid).

bonus.name: Spore Step
entries: The troll hag magically teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet of it.

reaction.name: Spawn Troll
entries: {@actTrigger} The troll hag takes damage. {@actResponse} Create one Fungal Trolling in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the troll hag. The fungal trolling acts immediately after the triggering creature's turn, then after the troll hag's turn on subsequent rounds.

spellcasting.name: Coven Magic
headerEntries: While within 30 feet of at least two hag allies, the hag can cast one of the following spells, requiring no Material components, using the spell's normal casting time, and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks).

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The troll hag casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}):

1: {@spell Scrying The hag may replace either its Fungal Staff or Slimeball attack with the following:}

trait.name: Fungal Aura
entries: The ground in a 10-foot radius of any of the three hags is difficult terrain and grants the hags half cover as it is covered in constant fungal growths and clouds of spores unless the hag has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. {@actSave con} {@dc 16}, any creature who ends its turn within the area. {@actSaveFail} The target has the {@condition Staggered|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@condition Bewildered|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} conditions (save ends)

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The troll hag regains 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of each of its turns. If the troll hag takes Acid or Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the hag's next turn. The troll hag dies only if it starts its turn with 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The troll hag makes one Fungal Staff attack and one Slimeball attack. It can replace either attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Fungal Staff
entries: {@actSave int} {@dc 14}, one creature within 5ft. {@actSaveFail} 16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) Psychic damage and the target has the {@condition Addled|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition (save ends).

action.name: Slimeball
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6}, range 30/120 ft. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) Acid damage and the target has the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition ({@dice 3d10} Acid).

action.name: Garden of Fungal Delights {@recharge}
entries: The coven pours their strange brew upon the mushroom patches around them, immediately spawning 7 ({@dice 2d6}) Fungal Trollings.

action.name: Rapid Growth (1/Day)
entries: If all three hags use their action to target the same fungal trolling within 60 feet of them with this ability, that trolling erupts in size and becomes a Humongous Fungus Troll. While the hags are using this ability, they must maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}. If any of the hags lose {@status Concentration|XPHB} before the third hag takes its action, the ability is not wasted but they must start over. While being targeted by Rapid Growth, the targeted fungal trolling has the {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Vexing Curse
entries: {@actSave int} {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} 19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) Psychic damage and the target has the {@condition Jinxed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ({@dice 1d6}) condition (save ends).

trait.name: Absorbing Flesh
entries: A creature reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by the growth is absorbed into its body and dies. When it absorbs a creature, the growth's size increases by one category. If the growth finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} and hasn't absorbed a body since its last {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, its size decreases by one category.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The growth makes a number of attacks based on its size: two (Medium), three (Large), four (Huge) or five (Gargantuan).

action.name: Assimilating Pseudopod
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 10 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Necrotic damage, and if the target is smaller than the growth, it is subjected to the following effect. {@actSave dex} {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} The target is swallowed by the growth. A swallowed creature has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} and {@condition Restrained|XPHB} conditions, has {@variantrule Cover|XPHB|Total Cover} from attacks and effects outside the growth, and takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Necrotic damage and the start of each of the growth's turns. The growth regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the amount of Necrotic damage dealt, and excess healing increases its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Maximum.

If the growth takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the growth must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which land with the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition in unoccupied spaces within 10 feet of the growth. If the growth dies, a swallowed creature no longer has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition and can escape from the corpse using 20 feet of movement, exiting with the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

reaction.name: Adaptable Flesh
entries: {@actTrigger} The growth takes damage from a spell or attack. {@actResponse} The growth halves the damage it takes from the triggering spell or attack.

trait.name: Displacement
entries: The polyp's form is constantly shifting and moving through reality in unnatural ways. Attack rolls against the polyp have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}. If the polyp takes damage, this trait ceases to function until the start of its next turn. This trait is suppressed while the polyp has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} or {@condition Restrained|XPHB} conditions or is otherwise unable to move.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The polyp makes two Mucus attacks.

action.name: Mucus
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) Acid damage, and a 5-foot radius centered on the target is covered in acidic slime for 1 minute. A creature other than the polyp that enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there is subjected to the following effect. {@actSave con} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Acid damage, and the target has the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition ({@dice 3d6} Acid).

action.name: Slip Space
entries: The polyp teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet. {@actSave con} {@dc 15}, each creature in a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the polyp when it reappears. {@actSaveFail} 16 ({@damage 3d10}) Force damage. Failure by 5 or More: The target triggers an Arcane Anomaly centered on itself. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

bonus.name: Shift Step
entries: The polyp teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

reaction.name: Confused Realities
entries: {@actTrigger} The polyp takes damage from a creature it can see within 30 feet. {@actResponse} The triggering creature is teleported to an unoccupied space the polyp can see within 30 feet of its original space. The destination must be on a surface or liquid that can support the target without the target having to squeeze.

trait.name: From Another World
entries: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

trait.name: Keen Eye, Sharp Wit
entries: The void pirate has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} rolls.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The void pirate makes three attacks.

action.name: Void Longsword
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 9}, reach 5 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) Force damage.

action.name: Pirate Pistol
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 9}, range 30/120 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Piercing damage.

bonus.name: Bark Orders
entries: One void pirate squib or quartermaster within 60 feet of the void pirate can use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} or make an attack.

reaction.name: Captain's Command (2/Day)
entries: {@actTrigger} A {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} creature within 30 feet of the void pirate fails an attack roll. {@actResponse} If the creature can hear the void pirate, it can reroll the attack roll and use the higher result.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The void pirate casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Intelligence as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 14}, +6 to spell attacks):

trait.name: From Another World
entries: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

trait.name: Magical Chaos
entries: When the void pirate or a creature within 30 feet of it is targeted by a spell, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 4-5, an Arcane Anomaly triggers on the caster. On a 6, the spell fails and an Arcane Anomaly triggers on the caster.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The void pirate makes three Void Blast attacks.

action.name: Void Blast
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d10 + 3}) Force damage, and the target is knocked 10 feet away from the void pirate.

bonus.name: Summon Elemental (1/Day)
entries: The void pirate magically summons an Entropic Flame, Walking Geode, Living Deep Haze, or Animated Delerium Sludge. The elemental appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the void pirate, whom it obeys. It takes its turn immediately after the void pirate. It lasts for 1 hour, until it or the void pirate dies, or the void pirate dismisses it as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

trait.name: Captain's Orders
entries: While within 60 feet of a void pirate captain, the void pirate has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions.

trait.name: Duel to the Death
entries: Once per turn, if the Void Pirate is within 5 feet of an enemy, and no other creatures are within 5 feet of them, the void pirate can deal an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Slashing damage with their Voidblade attack.

trait.name: From Another World
entries: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The void pirate makes two attacks.

action.name: Voidblade
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) Force damage.

action.name: Boltgun
entries: {@atkr r} {@hit 6}, range 150/600 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) Piercing damage, and the target has the {@condition Slowed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition until the end of its next turn.

bonus.name: Bark Orders
entries: One void pirate squib within 60 feet of the void pirate can use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to move up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} or make an attack.

trait.name: Captain's Orders
entries: While within 60 feet of a void pirate captain, the void pirate has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions.

trait.name: From Another World
entries: The void pirate doesn't have the standard Aberrant Traits other creatures in the Space Between Worlds have.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The void pirate makes two Void Cutlass attacks or uses its Sturdy Net.

action.name: Void Cutlass
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) Slashing damage.

action.name: Sturdy Net
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 6}, reach 5 ft. or range 15/30 ft. {@h}The target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} and {@condition Defenseless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} conditions. A creature can take an action to free itself or another creature in a net with a successful {@dc 14} Strength check. Dealing 10 Slashing damage to the net (AC 12) frees the target without harming it and destroys the net.

bonus.name: Man the Cannons
entries: The void pirate loads an artillery weapon, such as a cannon or ballista.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: The elemental explodes when it dies and it hasn't taking Force, Radiant, or Thunder damage since its last turn. {@actSave con} {@dc 16}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the elemental. {@actSaveFail} 42 ({@damage 12d6}) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level. {@actSaveSuccessOrFail} The explosion triggers a random Arcane Anomaly (see Appendix C).

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two Shard Slam attacks.

action.name: Shard Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 10 ft. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) Bludgeoning damage. {@actSave con} {@dc 16}. {@actSaveFail} 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the gargoyle remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an inanimate statue.

trait.name: Faultless Tracker
entries: The creature that caused the gargoyle to animate becomes its quarry. The gargoyle knows the direction and distance to its quarry as long the quarry remains within Drakkenheim or until the gargoyle is destroyed.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If the wall gargoyle is destroyed, it reforms with all of its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} in 1 hour unless a {@spell Disintegrate|XPHB} spell is cast on its remains.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gargoyle makes one Bite attack and one Claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Slashing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ratling casts one of the following spells, requiring no Material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The ratling has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) Piercing damage.

action.name: Balefire
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d8 + 3}) Necrotic damage, and the target has the {@condition Burning|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition ({@dice 2d8} Necrotic).

action.name: Conjure Swarms (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The ratling conjures two Swarms of Rats, which appear in unoccupied spaces within 60 feet. The swarms act immediately after the ratling in {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}. The swarms remain for 1 minute or until destroyed.

bonus.name: Teleport
entries: The ratling teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 60 feet.

trait.name: Aberrant Traits
entries: The warp marauder has the traits described in the "Aberrant Traits" sidebar in the Monsters of Drakkenheim.

trait.name: Extraplanar Gullet
entries: The warp marauder's back opens into a large mouth that leads to an extradimensional gullet. Anything it swallows is transported into this extraplanar space, which manifests as a rhizomatic network of slurping tunnels and fleshy passages. This space can hold any number of creatures of any size, and nothing inside the space can harm the warp marauder.

A creature within the gullet can take an action to attempt to escape, making a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a success, it reappears in the nearest unoccupied space within 5 feet of the warp marauder. On a failure, it takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Psychic damage. If the warp marauder dies, everything inside the extraplanar gullet appears in the nearest unoccupied spaces to its corpse.

trait.name: Grasping Tentacles
entries: The warp marauder can have up to four tentacles at a time. Each tentacle has AC 20, 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to Poison and Psychic damage. Destroying a tentacle deals no damage to the warp marauder, which can extrude a replacement tentacle on its next turn. A creature within 5 feet can take an action to break a tentacle with a successful {@dc 15} Strength check.

trait.name: Swirling Color Field
entries: A field of shimmering color reverberates around the warp marauder, distorting reality. A creature that hits the warp marauder with an attack suffers one of the following effects, determined randomly (roll {@dice 1d6}). A creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} and adjacent to the warp marauder isn't affected by the Swirling Color Field.

trait.name: 1-2: Blue
entries: The attacker is teleported to an unoccupied space the warp marauder can see within 20 feet. The chosen space must be on a surface or in a liquid that can support the target. The attacker is then subjected to the following effect. {@actSave cha} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} The target has the {@condition Immobilized|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition (save ends).

trait.name: 3-4: Yellow
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} 21 ({@damage 6d6}) Lightning damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

trait.name: 5-6: Red
entries: {@actSave wis} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} The target has the {@condition Staggered|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition (save ends).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The warp marauder makes four Tentacle attacks, uses Reel, and makes one Bite attack.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 60 ft. {@h}The target has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 15}). While {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition and has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength checks and saving throws, and the warp marauder can't use this tentacle against another target.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft, one creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the warp marauder. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) Piercing damage, and the warp marauder swallows the target. The target, along with everything it is wearing and carrying, appears in the warp marauder's Extraplanar Gullet.

action.name: Reel
entries: The warp marauder pulls each creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by it up to 30 feet straight toward it.

bonus.name: Dimensional Jump
entries: The warp marauder teleports to an unoccupied space within 120 feet. Alternatively, it travels from the Material Plane to the Space Between Worlds or vice versa.

reaction.name: Reality Hunter
entries: {@actTrigger} A creature {@condition Grappled|XPHB} by the warp marauder attempts to teleport. {@actResponse d}{@actSave int} {@dc 15}. {@actSaveFail} 21 ({@damage 6d6}) Force damage, and the teleport fails. {@actSaveSuccess} The teleport fails, but no resources are wasted.

monster.name: Warp Witch
languages: The languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The warp witch can move through other creatures and objects as if they were {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XPHB}. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) Force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

action.name: Balefire Lantern
entries: {@atkr m,r} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d8 + 3}) Cold damage, and the target has the {@condition Slowed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition until the end of the warp witch's next turn.

action.name: Psychic Scream
entries: {@actSave int} {@dc 13}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Psychic damage, and the target has the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition (save ends).

action.name: Possession
entries: {@actSave cha} {@dc 13}, one Humanoid the warp witch can see within 5 feet. {@actSaveFail} The target is possessed by the Warp Witch. The witch disappears, and the target has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition and loses control of its body. The witch controls the target's body but doesn't deprive the target of awareness. The witch can't be targeted by any attack, spell, or other effect, except ones that turn undead. The witch retains its alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions. It otherwise uses the possessed target's game statistics, but doesn't gain access to the target's knowledge, class features, or proficiencies.

The possession lasts until the body drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the witch ends it as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, or the witch is turned or forced out by an effect like the {@spell Dispel Evil and Good|XPHB} spell. When the possession ends, the witch reappears in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the body. If the target succeeds on its save or the effect ends for it, it is immune to this warp witch's {@variantrule Possession|XPHB} for 24 hours.

bonus.name: Mutate Host
entries: {@actSave cha} {@dc 13}, one creature the warp witch is possessing. {@actSaveFail} The target gains one {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level and a mutation.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The troll regains 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of each of its turns. If the troll takes Fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the troll's next turn. The troll dies only if it starts its turn with 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Special Immunities
entries: The troll is immune to the {@condition Frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition(s).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The troll makes two Slam attacks and one Bite attack. It can replace its Bite attack with Freezing Breath, if available.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) Piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) Cold damage, and the target has the {@condition Slowed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition until the end of the troll's next turn. Critical {@h}The target has the {@condition Frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition (escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 7}, reach 5 ft. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) Bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) Cold damage.

action.name: Freezing Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 16}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 18 ({@damage 4d8}) Cold damage and has the {@condition Frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition (escape {@dc 16}). {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage only.

trait.name: Conditioned Obedience
entries: While the patient can see its creator, it has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

action.name: Rusty Surgical Blade
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Poison damage.

reaction.name: Protective Impulse
entries: {@actTrigger} The patient's creator is targeted by an attack or spell, and the patient is within 10 feet of it. {@actResponse} The patient switches spaces with its creator and becomes the target instead.

spellcasting.name: Mage Hand
headerEntries: The dragon casts {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB} using Charisma as the spellcasting ability. The hand created by the spell is invisible.

trait.name: Aberrant Traits
entries: The dragon has the traits described in the "Aberrant Traits" sidebar in the Monsters of Drakkenheim.

trait.name: Epic Boss Hit Points
entries: Increase Young Delerium Dragon's starting hit points and hit dice by 52 ({@dice 5d10 + 25}) for each player character above four, or reduce its starting hit points and hit dice by that amount for each player character below four.

trait.name: Haze Aura
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the dragon takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) Necrotic damage.

action.name: The dragon always takes its turn on Initiative count 20
entries: On its turn, the dragon can use its movement and interaction as normal. However, it does not take an action or {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} on its turn unless forced to do so by a spell or other effect. Instead, the dragon takes one of the following {@variantrule Epic Action|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Epic Actions} at the end of each player character's turn:

items.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 10}, reach 10 ft. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) Force damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 18}). While {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition.

items.name: Contaminated Rend
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 18}, one creature within 5 feet of the dragon. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Necrotic damage, and the target gains one {@condition Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} level.

items.name: Tail
entries: {@actSave str} {@dc 18}, one creature within 20 feet of the dragon. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Force damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Prone|XPHB} condition.

action.name: Octarine Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: {@actSave dex} {@dc 18}, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Necrotic damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Psychic damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) Radiant damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

action.name: Dimension Hop (1/Round)
entries: The dragon teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 30 feet.

action.name: Epic Resistance
entries: The dragon chooses one condition, spell, or other effect currently affecting them and rolls {@dice 1d20}. On an 11+, the effect ends on it. The dragon can use this action even if it would otherwise be unable to take actions, its actions are being controlled by another creature, or if a spell or effect alters its game statistics.

trait.name: Unshakeable Faith (1/Day)
entries: When the zealot would fail a saving throw, it can reroll the save with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}. It must use the new roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The zealot makes two Greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 5}, reach 5 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) Slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) Radiant damage.

bonus.name: For the Flame (1/Day)
entries: Allies of the zealot within 60 feet of it that can hear it gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls and saving throws until the start of the zealot's next turn.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The vampire has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on melee attack rolls against a creature with the {@variantrule Bloodied|XPHB} condition.

trait.name: Blood Shield
entries: Whenever the vampire damages a creature that has blood, the vampire gains 15 {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The vampire regains 10 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampire takes Radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The vampire can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Vampire Weaknesses
entries: The vampire has the traits described in the "Vampire Weaknesses" sidebar in the Monsters of Drakkenheim.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vampire makes three attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Bite.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 8}, reach 5 ft. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) Slashing damage, and if the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape {@dc 21}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@actSave con} {@dc 16}, one creature within 5 feet that is willing or has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB}, {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB}, or {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition. {@actSaveFail} 15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) Necrotic damage. The target's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Maximum decreases by an amount equal to the Necrotic damage taken, and the vampire regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to that amount.

bonus.name: Morrigan's Fury (1/Short Rest)
entries: The vampire howls at the moon, gaining {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to all damage except Acid and Radiant damage for 1 minute or until it has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. As part of this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, the vampire moves up to half its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} toward a {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} creature without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB} action.

monsterFluff.name: Amalgamation

entries: Before the throne is a gibbering amalgamation of fleshy tumors, rotting bones, and rancid layers of bloated fat suspended between the ceiling and floor by stalky strands of gnarled tissue. A palpable aura of contamination emanates from the beast. The mass is covered in bursting sores and shuddering mucus nodule that weep bile and delerium sludge. The creature mutters in alien tongues from six yawning mouths, piping and sputtering in discordant musical tones, and lazily shifting eyes of massive size open and close throughout its bulk. Thick trunk-like tentacles reach out from its hideous stinking form to squirm and writhe around the chamber. Several appendages are wrapped around pulsing human organs: lungs, liver, kidney, a heart, a brain, and dangling amongst them is the jeweled Crown of Westemär.
Dwelling within the throne room of Castle Drakken is the Amalgamation, the result of a cascading catastrophe of contamination and mutation.

When the meteor struck, several magical occurrences happened almost instantaneously throughout the city. The Fracturing of the Inscrutable Tower triggered haywire arcane anomalies through the city, while the impact of the meteor sent a shockwave of magical devastation that shattered glass, blew through stone and wood, and reduced most living creatures to ash. Others caught in the blast were instantly transformed into monsters, and buildings and streets were shifted into sentient growths and misshapen horrors.

Castle Drakken was an epicenter of magical wards, protective spells, divination, and all manner of inherently magical trinkets and artifacts. The throne room where King Ulrich sat housed several of the most powerful magical relics in Westemär. The Crown of Westemär being the most prominent, although King Ulrich himself held a magical scepter, wore four magical rings, and a possessed a protective amulet. Furthermore, the large circular stained glass window behind the throne was imbued with magic that allowed it to change colors and depict different images throughout the seasons.

Naturally, when the rippling wave of arcane destruction blasted through the throne room, it fractured the abundant magical energies within the room, immediately opening a rift to the Space Between Worlds (see chapter 8) and amalgamating all the king's men into a massive mound of rippling fatty flesh. King Ulrich tried to escape but the magical mayhem fused him to his throne. As the King melted, he was absorbed by the expanding flesh, his face coming to rest as a disfigured grimace placed in the center of the horrible Amalgamation.

The creature continued to grow as the years passed, and those who went searching for the lost king would soon become one with the Amalgamation as well. Tendrils of strange flesh now spread like a web of sinew and skin across the throne room while pulsing contamination ripples out of the grotesque mass. A massive maw spans the length of the creature with various human bones posing as jagged and sharp teeth. Its tongue is a writhing mass of intestines and gore. No longer can any semblance of those lost to the Amalgamation be found. The king's face still prominently sits above the creature's massive maw, a mocking display of the fragility of the empires of a world not ready to face horrors beyond their comprehension.

The Amalgamation has a multidimensional form that straddles the Material Plane and the Space Between Worlds. Its mere presence acts as an anchor for the dimensional rift that pulls more and more contamination into Drakkenheim.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters who have one or more mutations, or who are afflicted with any form of madness gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} the Amalgamation, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (20+) Multidimensional
entries: You recognize its {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, and its Rejuvenation, Malignancy, and Immutable Form traits.

entries.name: (25+) Insatiable Hunger
entries: You know of the creature's Bite attack, as well as its Mind-Breaking Whispers ability.

entries.name: (30+) Beyond Comprehension
entries: You are aware of its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Amalgamation is a formidable foe capable of grappling multiple targets and eating them or throwing them around the battlefield. It constantly summons {@creature Pyknic Maunder|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Pyknic Maunders} as additional support while it uses Mind-Breaking Whispers to shatter the minds of its greatest threats.
The Amalgamation does not fear any mortal creature, believing itself indestructible to mortal means. It does not flee or cower.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Aberration.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Flesh, Guts.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Tentacles, Teeth.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin.

entries.name: Dust:
entries: Aberrant Dust.

entries.name: Trophy:
entries: {@item The Crown of Westemär|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}

monsterFluff.name: Anomollusk

entries: A colossal snail as wide as a city street with a shell the size of a small house glides slowly into view. Its shell has a kaleidoscopic fractal shimmer, projecting hues of unknown colors that swirl in incomprehensible patterns. As it moves, its shell seems to refract light in ways that seem nonsensical or wrong. You must strain your eyes to look at it wriggle towards you. Its bulbous head ends in two long antennae each holding a small octarine eye. Slimy mucus drips off its flesh, leaving sizzling trails and corroding anything it touches.

When a simple snail latches onto a delerium shard, there is a slight chance it fuses with its shell. These humble creatures can grow to massive proportions if they survive the contamination. Over time, the shells merge with more delerium, mutating the snails into chaotic conduits for erratic magic called an Anomollusk.

Its defensive crystalline shells can also absorb arcane energy. This adaptation disrupts nearby magic, rendering spells and magical weapons unreliable. Attacking an Anomollusk with magic is dangerous, causing wild magic flares and arcane anomalies, giving the creature its name. Driven to consume contaminated flora, Anomollusks inadvertently collect magical energy, making them especially valuable for creating magic items.

Anomollusks are predominantly found in areas like Queen's Park Garden, where the flora is richly imbued with magic. Though sometimes seen in the city's outskirts, they prefer heavily contaminated areas such as around the Crater's Edge. These creatures absorb and occasionally release magical energy from the environment, unleashing sporadic bursts of chaotic magic in the landscape.

In their wake, Anomollusks leave trails of acidic decay—ichors far too toxic even for their bodies to contain for long. Moving with lackadaisical whimsy, they etch eerie patterns into stone and metal, occasionally resembling arcane runes when observed from above. If there is any meaning or purpose behind these markings, none can say for certain.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} an Anomollusk, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (10+) Powerfully Protected
entries: You learn its {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} as well as its Shell Reflection Reaction.

entries.name: (15+) Dangerous Slime
entries: You are aware of its Snail Trail and Creep abilities.

entries.name: (20+) Slow and Simple Minded
entries: You recognize its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Drawn to magic, Anomollusk's view spellcasters and those equipped with magic items as delicious morsels. It attacks by first using its Creep action before it tries to Slobber on them. If threatened, it tries to cover the enemy and its territory in acidic slime. If reduced to less than half Hit Points, it attempts to flee.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Goopy Ooze, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Guts, Glands.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Shell, Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Arcane Wraith

entries: Tattered purple robes hang off the ethereal skeleton drifting silently through the air. Its rune-inscribed skull menacingly chants arcane words as points of octarine light flare from the dark holes of its eyes. Ghostly tendrils flicker and five Academy rings jangle as it raises a skeletal hand, enacting the arcane gestures of its first spell.

An Arcane Wraith is the disembodied, corrupt, undead spirit of an arcane spellcaster who perished violently in Drakkenheim. Delerium affects people with magical skill in unpredictable ways. In their death throes, those with mageborn blood may transform into vile undead, eternally bound to the Haze while retaining a portion of their arcane power twisted into malevolent, shadowy forms. Arcane Wraiths relentlessly hunger for both magical essence and life force. They are particularly aggressive towards living spellcasters, but readily attack anyone carrying magic items, spell components, or delerium crystals.

These wraiths are most frequently seen near highly magical areas, like the Inscrutable Tower, however, they have been spotted elsewhere in the Inner City, and rarely, outside the city walls. Places like potion shops and a mage's former residence are also common haunts for an Arcane Wraith.

Left alone, these spirits ponderously study arcane phenomena, often drawing paradoxical conclusions. They collect scrolls, and spellbooks while scribbling rambling notes. Occasionally, their mad research may uncover a genuine revelation, but discerning discovery from delusion amidst their tattered scrawlings is difficult. A careful approach may allow one to converse with these undead. However, their speech is a convoluted mixture of half-remembered incantations, loquacious postulations, and incoherent babbling. They quickly grow frustrated when interlocutors fail to grasp the brilliance of their work.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to Study an Arcane Wraith, learning the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Contaminated Undead
entries: You know the Arcane Wraith's Immunities and Resistances.

entries.name: (10+) Spellcaster's Spirit
entries: You are aware of its Comet Shards and Nightmare Pattern actions.

entries.name: (15+) Unstable Intellect
entries: You recognize the monster's strongest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Arcane Wraiths take advantage of their Incorporeal Movement, gliding through walls and small openings, before blasting targets with Comet Shards from above. They use Nightmare Pattern to control foes and focus attacks on those unaffected by the illusion. Occasionally, they collaborate with other undead, such as Haze Husks and Haze Wights, commanding them like apprentices or minions.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Undead.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Contaminated Ichor, Ectoplasm.

entries.name: Dust:
entries: Undead Dust.

entries.name: Items:
entries: Arcane Wraiths often have {@dice 1d3} uncommon potions or spell scrolls collected nearby and may occasionally have a spellbook with {@dice 2d6} wizard spells of 3rd level and lower scribbled inside.

monsterFluff.name: Beetle Knight

entries: Two insectoid legs hold up the beetle-like creature, rhythmically clacking as it skitters about. Two clawed arms scrabble beneath blade-like limbs as gnashing mandibles chitter under its beady eyes. A massive pincer-like horn protrudes from its helmet-shaped head and a tough blueish-silver shell protects delicate wings hidden beneath.

Beetle Knights represent the mutations found within even the smallest creatures in the aftermath of the meteor's strike. Insects that once crawled up from the soil, out of wall cracks, or from between floor boards have been transformed by contact with delerium and exposure to the Haze. Many have grown monstrously, to humanoid size or even larger.

Beetle Knight shells are thick enough to protect them from most attacks. Their name comes from the way their shells have mutated to resemble plate armor, while scything hands and a massive horn look like a pair of blades and an ornate helm. At a glance, these creatures resemble an armored knight ready for battle.

Beetle Knights commonly hide within the ruins and sewers of Drakkenheim, feeding on Deep Dregs and other smaller creatures. Occasionally, at night, or after heavy rains, Beetle Knights emerge in large numbers, to surprise and overwhelm the unprepared.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to study a Beetle Knight, revealing the following based on the result:

entries.name: (5+) Alien and Unflinching
entries: You identify its condition Immunities.

entries.name: (10+) Watch Out for that Horn!
entries: You recognize its Fling {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, and Pincer Horn action.

entries.name: (15+) Slow and Unintelligent
entries: You know its strongest and weakest saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Beetle Knight is surprisingly agile, rarely standing still in battle. They charge during the first round, flinging enemies aside or attempting to grapple. If possible, they back up to charge again but will otherwise defend with their arm blades. They attempt to flee losing battles where their {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} fall below half their maximum.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Guts.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Blades, Mandibles.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Carapace.

monsterFluff.name: Belfray

entries: A shrill screech pierces the air as a large, misshapen bat swoops overhead. Its outstretched wings resemble elongated human arms, with flesh pulled taut to its deformed body. Rows of hooked fangs fill its maw below bulging, red eyes and a sniveling snout.

Once a common sight, bats in Drakkenheim have swelled in both number and form. Many are now as large as dogs with wingspans stretching almost six feet. Insects no longer satisfy their thirst for blood and they crave the taste of flesh.
Belfrays are nocturnal and seldom encountered during the day. Even within the Haze, they prefer the nightly octarine glow to the strange hazy days.

When night falls, Belfrays gather atop old towers and flutter through the streets. They can be found hanging from old lamp posts and in the rafters of ruined houses, waiting to swoop down upon passing creatures. They are most often found in the city's highest locations such as {@i Castle Drakken}, the Clock Tower, the Inscrutable Tower, and some of the city's larger buildings.

Belfrays mostly feast on {@creature Ratlings}, but many victims have been surprised by these creatures swarming from the darkness. One should always be wary of damp and dark spaces where a handful of Belfrays could lurk. Disturbing them might be your last mistake.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Belfray, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Accustomed to the Dark
entries: You understand the Belfray's damage {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}.

entries.name: (10+) Flying Blood-Drinker
entries: You recognize its Flyby and Keen Hearing features, and Enfeebling Bite attack.

entries.name: (15+) Weak Mind
entries: You know the Belfray's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Belfray attempts to strike with a Sonic Blast from the shadows before engaging. Once a target is weakened, it swoops in with its claws. When damaged, Belfrays Bite, feeding on the blood of their victims to regain strength. It uses movement to stay away from threats, diving to attack before flying to a safe distance. If reduced below half of its maximum Hit Points, it attempts to fly away.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Heart, Guts.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Skull, Spine.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Claws, Teeth.

entries.name: Hair:
entries: Fur.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin, Webbed Membrane.

monsterFluff.name: Big Linda

entries: The ground shudders beneath the approach of a monstrosity: a pale, green-white, bipedal reptile. A huge mouth dominates its skull-like face, as acidic saliva drips between rows of razor-sharp teeth. Spines run down its back and tail, and its great body is supported by two trunk-like legs, though its feeble forearms appear nearly useless. It roars a sound like rent metal as it charges forward to devour you.

Hidden beneath the ruins of Drakkenheim, the enigmatic {@b Queen of Thieves} has a vast arena where the ambitious battle for a chance to win her favor. Those who climb its ranks must ultimately face the Queen's favorite pet: a monstrous reptilian creature affectionately nicknamed “Big Linda.” Should any survive a minute in the pit—or manage to slay the beast—the Queen of Thieves promises anything within her power to grant. Of course, no one has yet claimed this prize.

Pit fighters are often puzzled by the Queen's calm smirk when they believe they can gain her favor. Few realize that each victory brings them ever closer to a tragic end in Big Linda's jaws while a crowd of thieves cheers on their gruesome deaths.

Big Linda was first spotted in the ruins near King's Gate hunting trolls. No creature like her has been seen, and it remains unclear how the Queen captured the beast. It's thought that she herself played a role, since no one hired for the mission is still alive. Even the crew she paid to deliver the caged beast met their deaths at the hands of a Hooded Lanterns patrol shortly thereafter.

It remains a mystery what creature transformed to become Big Linda, perhaps a mutated bird, or an overgrown gecko. The only creature remotely resembling it is the old dinosaur skeleton in the Drakkenheim museum, but even then, the many differences bring up a slew of questions as to its origin.

Although the Queen keeps Big Linda well-fed and securely contained, she is aware the monstrosity is barely under her control. Maintaining the beast's feeding schedule of fresh “challengers” is difficult and few handlers last more than a week before being gobbled up. The position is seen as a death sentence rather than any position of prestige amongst the Queen's Men.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} Big Linda, revealing the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Hard to Kill
entries: You know Big Linda's damage {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} as well as its Rejuvenation and Regeneration traits.

entries.name: (15+) Acidic Mucus!
entries: You're aware of her Acid Spew attack.

entries.name: (20+) Big, Clumsy, and Dumb
entries: You recognize Big Linda's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Big Linda sends Acid Spew against groups of opponents. She then tries to optimize her Bite and Tail attacks by placing herself within her enemies. She is hesitant to leave the Deep Haze but is also not smart enough to resist chasing those who antagonizing her. She rarely flees unless severely wounded, wherein she will seek the safety of the Deep Haze to recover.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Guts, Glands, Flesh.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Teeth.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Bigger Linda

entries: Thundering through the streets of Drakkenheim with a crash, the infamous pet of the Queen of Thieves has mutated and enlarged to unfathomable proportions. The Haze swirls around it, and octarine energy pulses in its sunken eye sockets. The broken hafts of weapons and old arrows are embedded into its scales, stuck deeply between its regenerated flesh. Its spined back is illuminated by webs of glowing octarine veins; its wide snout is filled with jagged teeth. As it opens its maw wide, the building contaminated energy at the back of its throat begins to glow.

If {@creature Big Linda|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} ever escapes the confines of the {@creature Queen of Thieves|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, the beast will no doubt return to the ruins of Drakkenheim and immediately seek out new hunting grounds. However, Big Linda's containment has stunted her true growth potential. Once freed, the longer Big Linda spends directly exposed to the energies the Haze, the more she grows. As she grows, new mutations begin to form, further amplifying her ferocity, predatory senses, and resilience. If left unchecked, Big Linda might become the apex predator of Drakkenheim—Bigger Linda.

monsterFluff.name: Bloated Hive

entries: Dripping with sweet smelling pus and mucus, the creature shuffles about on spindly limbs like a gangly ape. It has long gnarled fingers and an emaciated whip-cord thin frame. Where there should be a head there is instead a mass of pulsing flesh covered in gaping pores that extend down its neck and across its shoulders. Its body writhes with thousands of bugs crawling beneath its skin and swarming around its head. They burrow in and out of open wounds and sores and buzz in and out of its pores. It smells faintly of honey and sweat, and gurgles painfully amidst the chorus of buzzing and clicking of insects, as if the thing is painfully aware of its wretched state.

The Bloated Hive is a product of contamination that seems to have turned people into walking hives of insects. Some suspect the honey farms on the outskirts may have been the main source of these strange mutations, causing the apiarists and their hives to warp together, fusing into a grotesque and tortured creature. Their upper torso and head are now a writhing mass of open pores like a beehive, with bugs swarming in and out. They lumber around the ruins looking for nesting places where their hive can thrive. Many Bloated Hives operate alone, but sometimes a much more horrifying event occurs, where a single colony begins to occupy multiple Bloated Hives, forming a horrifying network.

The Bloated Hive tends to hide itself in the dark corners of ruins, often seeking the most damp and warm locations in the city. Many hives have been found along the Drann River within the Inner City, a large group of them living under Champion's Bridge, and even more in the sewers, Queen's Park Garden, and a sparse few in the woods to the north of Drakkenheim. Whenever traversing into dark and damp areas in the city, be on the lookout for an increase in insect activity and the sound of buzzing.

A Bloated Hive cannot speak, and acts on the whims of its occupants more so than its own free thought. Its mind is now a broken thing, connected inherently to the hive mind of a swarm of insects, but within that is a tortured human struggling for sentience. Some Bloated Hives have been known to respond to kind words, trinkets of their former selves, or music they recognize. Though these moments of subtle sentience are fleeting, as the hive reacts quickly to the feeling of an unwanted psyche struggling for dominance within the hive mind and could trigger a frenzied tantrum if not handled delicately.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Bloated Hive, recognizing the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Sightless Awareness
entries: You know the creature's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities} and senses.

entries.name: (10+) Endless Insects!
entries: You are aware of the creature's Spawn Swarm action and Disrupt the Hive trait.

entries.name: (15+) Frail
entries: You recognize the Bloated Hive's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Bloated Hive is usually a solitary creature that spends its time cowering in dark corners living out its cursed life as nothing more than a conduit for its colony. In combat, they focus entirely on keeping their distance from threats and spawning swarms of insects to defend themselves. If cornered, the Bloated Hive uses its Claws and Distracting Swarm before moving back into the shadows and attempting to escape and find a new nest.

Larger packs of Bloated Hives are much braver and more violent, and actively hunt and pursue targets until their numbers are less than their prey. Places where large colonies gather are dangerous. The Bloated Hives work in unison to protect their nests. Only if they become outnumbered do they flee.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

monsterFluff.name: Bojack

entries: This creature, which appears to be a dead horse flopped on its back, convulses and its stomach suddenly splits open, exposing its intestines and organs. Long, spindly, arachnid-like legs violently sprout from its torso as its stomach opens into a maw filled with sharp jagged teeth formed from the splayed rib cage of the beast. The horse legs limply hang in the air, as the creature skitters towards you with intense speed, intestines flapping around its maw like a sickly tongue. The head of the horse dangles lifelessly, but its mouth still gnashes and salivates acidic bile.

Many valiant warriors have ridden into Drakkenheim mounted on a loyal steed, not realizing that the rubble and wreckage filling the streets makes the ruins an unsuitable environment for a horse. Often, these poor animals must be abandoned not long after entering the ruins, injured from the unstable terrain. Prime targets for other predators, the horses are often tragically slaughtered. However, when their corpses are left behind, a parasite-like mutation festers within them, causing their skin to erupt with spider-like limbs, pincers, and maws.

Disguising themselves as mere corpses strewn across the dark and misty streets of the ruined city, one can hardly differentiate a Bojack from a dead horse. With their spider limbs they can scurry along walls and ceilings with ease, and barely make a sound. They move with lightning-fast speed, able to scuttle across a city street in mere seconds. This terrifying speed, ease of traversing the terrain, and ability to disguise itself have made them a deadly threat to adventurers in the city.

One of the most horrifying recorded encounters with Bojacks in Drakkenheim came from an early report from Hooded Lantern scouts investigating old stables south of Champion's Gate near the city outskirts. They reported finding "piles of dead horses buzzing with large, mutated flies feasting on the meat." The report goes on to speak of several of the horse corpses suddenly "bursting open" with "insectoid legs and a horrible maw formed from the splayed rib cage of the dead beasts." The report describes the speed and ferocity displayed in the immediate strike, with nearly an entire squad of eight Hooded Lantern scouts ripped to shreds in only a matter of seconds while the remaining Lanterns fled back out of the city.

One of the surviving Hooded Lanterns, Sten Livingston Sr., was brave enough to volunteer to lead the following expedition into the ruins. On the road into the city a dead and bloated horse corpse lay on the side of the road. Livingston stopped his troops and approached the beast with weapons drawn, kicking the corpse to check if it would spring to life. The corpse remained motionless. It has since become a tradition spread through the Lanterns, and even into new adventuring parties, to kick the horse on the way into Drakkenheim. Many have chalked this up to a sign of good luck, not realizing the harrowing story and the lives lost that caused this strange tradition.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to Study a Bojack, learn the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Parasitic Mutation
entries: You recognize the Bojack's Immunities and senses.

entries.name: (15+) Acidic Ambusher
entries: You're aware of the creature's Corrosive Mucus and Impaling Limbs attacks.

entries.name: (20+) Fast and Cunning
entries: You know the Bojack's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Bojack is an ambush skirmisher. It waits for the opportune moment to strike, attempting to surprise as many targets as possible. After it surprises its prey, it attacks with its Impaling Limbs or Corrosive Mucus and uses its Predatory Cunning to move out of melee range.

The Bojack can climb walls and will try and skitter up buildings or behind walls, springing back out to attack before escaping again. If brought below 20 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the Bojack attempts to {@action Dash|XPHB} away and {@action Hide|XPHB}.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:

monsterFluff.name: Chitter

entries: Scampering up the wall is a creature the size of a hound. It resembles a mostly hairless squirrel save for its bushy tail and patchy tufts of mottled fur. Its eyes are glassy and milk white, and its mouth seems almost human, sporting huge, pearly white teeth that grin maniacally. It frantically clambers upward, while chittering a maddening chorus with its clacking teeth.

The Queen's Park Gardens are one of the most heavily contaminated areas in the city. Its massive gardens and trails were once a place of lush beauty, thick with trees, floral arrangements, topiary masterpieces, tranquil groves, and an abundance of wildlife. Drakkenheim's contamination warped all things, monstrously changing the creatures within. Now even the squirrels, which occupied the gardens in large numbers, are feral and mutated. Those wandering forested areas should be wary of chittering sounds echoing through the trees. These monsters attack in numbers, their clacking teeth maddening those nearby. The once friendly squirrels that locals would stop to feed now feed whether you want them to or not.

Chitters are also encountered along the heavily wooded northern outskirts of Drakkenheim and much of the farmlands surrounding the city. These places are not free from contamination; Chitters have been seen roaming like packs of feral dogs through the fields or lurking near woods. Chitters now occasionally roam the streets in the center of the city, climbing towers and buildings before leaping down onto their prey. No longer confined to the gardens, the city is their hunting ground and its ruins make wonderful homes for packs of Chitters.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Chitter, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Wall Crawling
entries: You are aware of its climb speed, its Running Leap trait, and its Slow Fall feature.

entries.name: (10+) Madding Noise
entries: You know of its Chitter attack action.

entries.name: (15+) Simple Minded
entries: You recognize its mental ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Chitters often attack in a small group. Usually two to three that form a family will stick together. The mutated squirrels have been known to be quite territorial and hostile, even to other Chitter families who try to infringe on their territory.

Chitters are excellent climbers, capable of falling a great distance without fear of hurting themselves. It is not uncommon for Chitters to be found in tall buildings, or up on the top floor of ruined houses, or hard-to-reach rooftops or attics. Chitters charge their enemies and leap at them, attempting to disable them with their chittering, and relying on their Claws and Bite. Chitters protect their homes with determined ferocity, but if reduced to less than a third of their Hit Points, they leap and clamber away.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
