entries: Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Crater Wurm

entries: The earth trembles, vibrating pebbles and dust. A deep rumble wells from below. Suddenly, stone cracks, extruding a titanic wurm. It rears its massive head, opening a petal-like mouth filled with long jagged crystalline teeth all pointed into its throat. Its body is covered in muddy purple plates with octarine spines jutting from between. Its hot breath sends octarine slime flying as it dives toward you.

Those who dared venture into the Crater Basin returned with harrowing tales of the tremendous Crater Wurms. They describe the earth shaking moments before a gargantuan wurm breaches the surface, swallowing creatures in its path. Curiously, the wurms are only seen in the desolate crater. Few understand how such gigantic creatures, let alone multiple wurms, can survive here, or why they do not leave to hunt elsewhere.

In truth, Crater Wurms mainly subsist on inorganic minerals found in the dirt, mud, and rock they burrow through, requiring little organic matter. The wurm's gullet functions like a contaminated crucible: minerals, rock, and living matter are broken down and crystallized, with delerium expelled as waste. Crater Wurms spend most of their lives underground, creating miles of twisting tunnels filled with glittering delerium, only surfacing in the {@link Crater Basin} to reproduce. Though none have yet seen the event, the wurm's massive form splits, releasing young from the carcass.

Perhaps no creature in Drakkenheim is more responsible for the deeply rooted contamination than Crater Wurms. The continued existence of these monsters could see the world transform into a contaminated wasteland. Tunneling below the surface, they have spread contamination deep into the bowels of the earth. Indeed, all the crystals scattered across the surface, the rich veins of delerium near the Scar, and the great deposits around the Crater itself pale in comparison to the mass of delerium left buried far underground by the Crater Wurms.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} or {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks when they {@action Study|XPHB} a Crater Wurm, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (15+) Subterranean Threat
entries: You know it has {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} and that it creates tunnels when digging through rock.

entries.name: (20+) Earth Shaker
entries: You're aware of the Crater Wurms' Breach and Bite attacks.

entries.name: (25+) Blunderous Brute
entries: You recognize the Crater Wurms' strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Crater Wurms disregard other creatures, viewing them as only morsels to consume. All are as the dust of the earth to it—simply food. These wurms understand that creatures they devour often try to flee. Their favored tactic is to remain buried until their {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} detects movement. They then surface with its Breach action, making Bite attacks, swallowing nearby {@condition Prone|XPHB} creatures. They dive beneath the ground once at least one creature is swallowed, or if reduced to half its Hit Point maximum.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Heart, Guts.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Teeth, Needles.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Plates.

monsterFluff.name: Dark Growth

entries: The remains of a corpse is splayed across a ruined wall. A chaotic mass of jet-black brambles and vines pours from its torso, clinging to the nearby stonework. Branches have burst from its form, and its neck erupts into another mass of plant matter. The skull is severed from the body with its jaw unhinged and hanging in a horrible expression, stuck in place by the writhing vines. Throughout this Dark Growth, flowers bloom in iridescent neon hues and the smell of sweet pollen and decaying flesh fills the air. You hear gentle whispers from a distant voice, distinctly familiar and beckoning.

Contamination causes most plants to wither and die, but some thrive on it, absorbing water and delerium from the soil to mutate into deadly flora. In Drakkenheim's urban wasteland, suitable plots of fertile soil are scarce outside {@link Queen's Park Garden}, necessitating a creative adaptation to proliferate. These Dark Growths take root in the bodies of creatures through their infectious, delerium-infused spores.

Emitted from their blooming flowers, these spores drift silently throughout the air until they enter another creature's body through the ears, mouth, or nose. Once inside, these spores can lay dormant for some time, slowly contaminating their host with internal mutation which slowly decay their flesh and bone from within, transforming it into an ideal place for the Dark Growth to germinate. When the creature succumbs to contamination, or dies with the spores within it, the plant awakens. Consuming the internal organs of the dying infected, it suddenly and violently sprouts. Often, this transformation occurs so suddenly that the creature remains walking around, the Dark Growth using the corpse as a mobile shell so it may plant in an ideal location to spread future spores.

One apothecary reports a case where a knight returning from a mission into the Inner City had survived the journey relatively unscathed save for an excursion into the gardens where a puff of what they thought was pollen from strange iridescent flowers got in their eyes. The knight thought little of it, suffering no immediate effects. After returning to Emberwood, the knight complained of stomach cramps, nausea, and headaches, eventually passing out from the pain. The apothecary performed an emergency surgery, cutting the patient open only to have their intestines burst out like a barrage of meaty, thorn-covered brambles that attempted to strangle the apothecary. Their intestines had been completely replaced with plant matter that had fused into their guts.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Dark Growth, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Contaminated and Thriving
entries: You are aware of the Dark Growth's Resistances and Immunities.

entries.name: (10+) Deadly Spores
entries: You recognize the creature's Infection Spores action.

entries.name: (15+) Kill it with fire!
entries: You know the creature's Vulnerability to Fire, and its strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: A Dark Growth is a simple-minded plant. It uses Mimicry to lure passing creatures towards it, often mimicking the sounds of children or people in need. It entangles and infests any target near it, infecting it with its spores. The creature is a stationary plant and does not flee.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Plant.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Contaminated Ichor, Sap.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Flowers.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Stems.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Spores, Needles.

entries.name: Hair:
entries: Leaves.

entries.name: Dust:
entries: Plant Dust.

monsterFluff.name: Digipede

entries: Scuttling atop dozens of spindly legs, this grotesque creature resembles a mutated centipede grown to horrific proportions. A segmented body nearly thirty feet long undulates atop unnaturally bending limbs resembling emaciated human fingers. Elongated yellow fingernails crackle and scrape the ground menacingly as it moves. Dominating its fat, round head is a single, massive human-like eye that swivels frenetically with a disturbing, unyielding intensity. Its antenna sprouts above like an eyebrow, while tightly closed mandibles resemble bags under the eye. Its foremost finger-legs end in pincer-like talons thrumming with electricity.

Adventurers exploring the {@link Inner City} learn to heed the sound of scraping nails—a harbinger of the Digipede's approach. Nicknamed “house” centipedes for their prodigious size, Digipedes are nightmarish creatures with a disposition toward violence. Rather than consuming their prey, they leave the bodies of their lifeless victims abandoned in the desolate city streets.

How Digipedes came to be is unknown. Perhaps they originated from ordinary centipedes mutated by pools of contaminated sludge, manifesting humanlike features during their grotesque transformations. Alternatively, they may be the result of an ongoing metamorphosis, their forms continuing to twist and warp, fueled by the relentless magical forces of the Haze. A few attribute their creation to a powerful wizard hiding in the ruins known as the {@creature Pale Man}, claiming he commands them as spies and assassins. Finally, it's possible the beasts are not the product of contamination but a horrific experiment created within the Inscrutable Tower long before Drakkenheim fell.

Nevertheless, a Digipede is solitary, preferring to avoid others of its kind. A few ingenious adventurers have taken advantage of this curious trait, mimicking the creature's rhythmic scraping and generating bursts of static electricity to drive them off, or even guide them toward other threats. This secret is well known to vanguards of the Hooded Lanterns, who use Digipedes as a bizarre form of pest control against other threats haunting the ruins.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Digipede, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Charged Form
entries: You recognize the creature's Resistance to Lightning damage and that it has {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} thanks to its large antenna.

entries.name: (15+) Sharp and Shocking
entries: You are aware of the Digipede's Talons and Eye Beam actions.

entries.name: (20+) Insectile Predator
entries: You learn the creature's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Despite its size, a Digipede will try to hide along rooftops, dark corners, narrow alleys, and any crevice which can accommodate it. It launches its Eye Beam from hiding to hinder its prey's escape, then rips into them with its Talons and Bite. The electric shocks from its attacks disrupt the ability of its prey to effectively fight back.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Elemental Fluid.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Guts.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Claws.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Carapace.

monsterFluff.name: Drakkenheim Sewer Gator

entries: Surfacing from the rancid sewer waters is a terrible alligator nearly fifty feet long. A jagged ridge of delerium runs along its back, ending in a fell crown atop its head as pallid skin frames its octarine glowing eyes. A thick, purple tentacle-like tongue undulates out of its tooth-filled maw. Strong and sturdy legs support its scarred body, attesting to countless battles in the ruins.

Some creatures seem less affected by contamination, or perhaps are just lucky to only grow in size and ferocity. Reptiles are speculated to be more resistant to uncontrollable mutations than other creatures. The occasional gator making its way up the {@link Drann River} was always a problem, but now, stories of vicious lizards are becoming more bizarre and horrifying.

Rumors speak of a massive gator living in the sewers, with sightings in the Drann River or echoes of its growls heard from sewer grates. None who came close enough to verify its existence have yet survived. Some report half-submerged forms passing through sewer entrances, sometimes mistaking them for large turtles. Others tell of a large beast rumbling through the pipes under their feet. In the taverns of Emberwood, the creature has earned the nickname “the Gray Queen” due to her pale skin and delerium crown. Others have called it by other names: the Devil of the Drann or the Greater Gator. Some have suggested that multiple giant gators live in the dirty waters.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to study a Drakkenheim Sewer Gator, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Fearless Aquatic Predator!
entries: You learn the Drakkenheim Sewer Gator's condition Immunities and Swim speed.

entries.name: (10+) Watch out for its bite!
entries: You are aware of the creature's Crushing Bite and Death Roll actions.

entries.name: (15+) Get it out of the water!
entries: You know of the creature's Contaminated Regeneration trait.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Drakkenheim Sewer Gator is primarily aquatic, haunting the sewer system or the Drann River. These monstrosities lunge from the waters to grab prey, dragging it beneath the surface. Once a target is in its jaws, the gator Death Rolls until its victim stops moving. It is a cunning hunter, knowing how to disappear below murky waters, but it can be provoked to chase its prey. Out of the water it is vulnerable and flees if reduced below half its Hit Points.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Flesh.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Skull, Ribs, Spine.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Teeth.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Last Memory

entries: Seared into brick and cobblestone is the ashen silhouette of a human form. Not a trace of their body remains, the blackened stone capturing the last imprint of their existence, the moment they were incinerated by the meteor's eldritch fire. Inexplicably, the silhouette animates into distorted shapes, as distant screams and echoing anguished whimpers fill your ears.

These disembodied undead were formed the moment the meteor struck Drakkenheim. In a flash, those close to the impact were reduced to ash, but eldritch forces unleashed by the explosion trapped the memories of those it obliterated. Captured forever in that moment as silhouettes, a Last Memory is not a ghost or specter. They are not metaphysically connected to a living creature or its spirit—that creature is gone, annihilated body and soul by the eldritch fires which consumed them. Instead, these undead are pain, suffering, and misery given form in a gruesome instant. These spirits cannot be reasoned with nor spoken to, and cannot be aided or soothed. They are incapable of existing outside the singular event of their destruction, desiring only to force that moment into the minds of others, causing them to experience their anguish over and over again.

Even if the mere physicality of a Last Memory is destroyed, its lingering agony causes them to reappear, their endless torment a gravestone marking one lost to the meteor. Last Memories destroyed in the ruins of Drakkenheim return days later, emerging in a sorrowful chorus of screams that echo through the city.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Religion|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Last Memory, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Deathless Memory.
entries: You know the creature's monster type, Resistances, and Immunities.

entries.name: (10+) Painful Recall.
entries: You are aware of the creature's Anguish action.

entries.name: (15+) Weak Undead.
entries: You learn the creature's ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Last Memories can move along the ground or up walls, often hiding as shadows on the ground. They have even followed prey, appearing as a strange movement in one's peripheral vision, or a shifting shadow from an unknown source.

When they reveal themselves, Last Memories cry out in anguish, causing those nearby to suffer visions of their last moments, inducing emotional trauma to any who succumb to it. They grasp those nearby, terrorizing them with waves of sorrow. Last Memories seem to embody the raw emotions of their death, using those emotions as weapons against the living. They do not flee, for they do not cherish their existence. Their only purpose is to spread the fear and the pain of their own death before fading away, only to reappear days later to relive their agony.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Undead.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Ectoplasm, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Dust:
entries: Undead Dust.

monsterFluff.name: Loathsome Gag Fly

entries: This massive fly buzzes through the air, bobbing and darting with a loud buzz of its wings. Its huge eyes make up most of its round form, saliva and mucus oozing from its small mandibles. Its abdomen is slightly translucent, with a purplish green liquid sloshing around inside its bloated form. It screams in a strangely human voice that sounds like it is crying for help.

The flies grow fat in Drakkenheim. Corpses do not rot, which makes them excellent sources of food for the rats, Garmyr, and bugs of the city. Many bloated corpses are now ripe with large green maggots that feast on the dead contaminated flesh. When these maggots evolve into Loathsome Gag Flies, they buzz around areas of death in the city. Attracted to fresh corpses, or piles of dead bodies, or even following along with a group of {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} or {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} hoping to munch on bits of their flesh. The city cistern and the old well in Slaughterstone Square is a known hot spot for a large nest of Gag Flies.

The Gag Flies are bloated and overgrown flies whose acidic mucus has now formed a pouch that occupies most of their large thorax. Like all flies, they use this acidic mucus to dissolve possible food and prepare it for eating. Due to their large size, this results in a horrible experience for adventurers wandering past a group of these flies, who all vomit sprays of burning acid onto their prey and buzz down to feed on the burning targets.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Survival|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Loathsome Gag Fly, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Flying Monstrosity.
entries: You know the Gag Fly's creature type and speeds.

entries.name: (10+) Explosive Bile.
entries: You learn of the Gag Fly's Bloat Burst Reaction.

entries.name: (15+) Bestial Minded.
entries: You recognize the Gag Fly's highest and lowest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Loathsome Gag Fly is a simple-minded creature who wants to feed on flesh and lay larva on the corpses of the dead. It sprays acid on any creature that it sees nearby in an attempt to weaken it. It then lands on them and begins feeding.

Gag Flies usually attack in groups and care very little for the wellbeing of each other. As a matter of fact, when a Gag Fly is killed and explodes in a shower of acid, this usually causes other nearby flies to go into a feeding frenzy on targets sprayed in the gore, as they are drawn to any flesh dissolving in the acids of their mucus.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Acidic Bile, Mucus.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Guts, Glands.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Mandibles, Needles.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Carapace.

monsterFluff.name: Lob Frog

entries: The frog-like creature has sharp spines down its back, with mottled green and brown flesh; a large segmented mouth that bisects its face; and a large, black, soulless eye peering out from either side. Its insect-like pincers drip and gnash as it huddles close to a mound of translucent, sticky, octarine eggs throbbing and writhing with contaminated energy. It holds one of the throbbing spawn in its webbed hand, ready to hurl it directly at you.

The {@link Drann River} flows into Drakkenheim from the Kesselwald Forest to the northeast. On some of the especially quiet and warm nights, you could hear the chorus of croaking frogs from within the woods close to the river. These frogs were commonly found there, and large numbers of them would migrate down the Drann River into the northern parts of the city, especially around King's Gate. Today, the frog's migration continues, but now the contaminated waters of the Drann have caused the amphibians to bloat to horrific size, and also wildly changed their reproductive cycle.

These mutated monsters are now commonplace along the river and make crossing at any point dangerous. Their eggs do not hatch on their own but require a host body to feed on to complete the metamorphosis. For this reason, the frogs weaponize their contaminated eggs, tossing them at passing adventurers, scouts, and even other contaminated creatures, hence their moniker: “Lob” Frogs.

The Lob Frog produces hundreds of eggs and hedges its bets by throwing them at any creature it finds, hoping that a few of them have the opportunity to gestate into a newborn Lob Frog. Newly formed Lob Frogs always carry a minor element of the host. A Lob Frog formed from a Ratling may have rodent-like ears or whiskers, where one formed from a human may carry the host's eye color.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Lob Frog, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Poisonous Skin.
entries: You recognize the Lob Frog's Immunities and Poison Skin trait.

entries.name: (10+) Hurled Eggs.
entries: You are aware of the Lob Frog's Throw Frogspawn action.

entries.name: (15+) Assured Amphibian.
entries: You know the Lob Frog's Strength and Charisma ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Lob Frogs are keen to keep their distance from predators and threats, but are constantly on the lookout for hosts for their offspring. They attempt to lob their contaminated eggs at potential threats, hoping to produce more Lob Frogs. If confronted directly, their Poison Skin acts as a defense while they use their Standing Leap to escape unfavorable situations.

If a Lob Frog has at least two or more targets with attached eggs, or if they are reduced below half Hit Points, they leap away to find somewhere safe and wet to hide. They would rather not risk their life, and simply hope to infect as many targets as possible to continue their species.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity.

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor, Venom.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Brain, Guts, Glands, Flesh.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Skull, Spine, Ribs.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Teeth.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin, Webbed Membrane.

monsterFluff.name: Pale Man

entries: Standing impossibly still in the shadows, a tall, gaunt figure stares with eyes like dim lanterns. Its skin is chalk white, stretched tight over an emaciated frame. Its mouth curls into an uncanny smile far too wide for its face. Without a sound, it tilts its head, and you feel a cold wave of dread wash over you as its gaze locks with yours.

Little is known about the Pale Man, and less still is certain. Whispers speak of a spectral killer who stalks the ruins of Drakkenheim, appearing suddenly in the periphery before vanishing again into darkness. The few who claim to have survived an encounter speak of an unnatural stillness, of feeling watched long before the Pale Man was seen, and of an overwhelming urge to flee the moment his eyes met theirs.

Some believe the Pale Man to be a unique undead spirit, perhaps the remnant of a powerful mage who perished when the meteor struck. Others claim he is no ghost at all, but a living man who has been irreversibly twisted by the Haze and delirium, granting him supernatural resilience and abilities beyond mortal ken. A few dark rumors suggest he commands other horrors in the city, using them as his eyes and ears.

The Pale Man rarely strikes directly. Instead, he manipulates fear itself, unsettling his prey until they are too rattled to think clearly, then dispatches them with sudden and overwhelming violence. His motives remain inscrutable—he seems to kill without pattern, mercy, or need, as though compelled by a cruel instinct or sadistic amusement.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Arcana|XPHB} or {@skill Religion|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Arcana|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} the Pale Man, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (10+) Unnatural Resilience.
entries: You learn the Pale Man's monster type, Resistances, and Immunities.

entries.name: (15+) Fear Incarnate.
entries: You are aware of the Pale Man's Terror Gaze action.

entries.name: (20+) Predator's Precision.
entries: You know the Pale Man's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Pale Man is a consummate ambush predator. He prefers to stalk prey from concealment, sowing paranoia before striking. He uses his Terror Gaze to incapacitate or scatter groups, then isolates and eliminates targets one by one.

If pressed into open combat, he uses his unnatural agility to slip away, often retreating into darkness or vanishing from sight entirely, only to resume his hunt moments later. He never fights to the death unless cornered, and even then, he uses every trick at his disposal to escape.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity or Undead (uncertain).

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Claws.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Rat King

entries: A writhing, chittering mass of rats swarms together, their tangled tails knotted in a grotesque ball of living flesh and fur. Dozens of beady red eyes glint in the dim light, and hundreds of sharp teeth gnash in unison. The swarm moves as one, twisting and undulating, an amalgam of vermin animated by a singular, malevolent will.

Legends of rat kings—multiple rats whose tails have become knotted together—date back centuries, but in Drakkenheim these phenomena have taken on a far darker form. The contamination has fused these unfortunate creatures not just physically, but mentally and spiritually into a single predatory entity. The resulting monstrosity is more than the sum of its parts, capable of coordinated attacks, cunning feints, and a vicious survival instinct.

Rat Kings lurk in the darkest corners of the city's ruins, often in the basements of crumbling buildings, in sewer junctions, or deep beneath piles of refuse. Their presence is often heralded by an overpowering stench and an eerie, synchronized squeaking that seems to echo from all directions at once. They are known to command or coordinate with ordinary rat swarms, driving them into frenzied assaults on intruders.

Some scholars believe the Rat King's hive mind is the result of delirium-laced magic fusing the animals into a single organism. Others speculate that they are the accidental byproduct of a failed magical experiment, while certain cults whisper that the Rat King is a herald or servant of darker, verminous deities.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB} or {@skill Nature|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} a Rat King, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Many as One.
entries: You know the Rat King's creature type and condition Immunities.

entries.name: (10+) Coordinated Swarm.
entries: You are aware of its Swarm Assault and Coordinated Attack traits.

entries.name: (15+) Weak Links.
entries: You learn the Rat King's weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Rat King uses superior numbers and coordination to overwhelm foes, often sending allied swarms to harry and distract while it moves in for the kill. It strikes from multiple angles, using its tangled mass to entrap prey and prevent escape.
If seriously injured, the Rat King will attempt to scatter, individual rats breaking free from the knot to flee and later reform elsewhere.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Beast (mutated).

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Guts.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Teeth, Claws.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Fur, Skin.

monsterFluff.name: Rat Prince

entries: From the darkness emerges a tall, thin figure draped in a patchwork cloak of matted fur and ragged cloth. Beneath the hood, a long, twitching snout bristles with whiskers, and sharp, glinting eyes gleam with cunning malice. Its clawed hands clutch a crooked scepter adorned with gnawed bones, and at its feet scurry dozens of filthy rats that move in perfect unison with its gestures.

The Rat Prince is no mere beast, but a vile fusion of humanoid intellect and verminous instinct. It is said that it was once a human—perhaps a sorcerer, cultist, or thief—who was consumed by the contamination and the will of the vermin it commanded. Over time, its body twisted to match its new nature, until it was neither man nor rat, but something in between.

Unlike the mindless swarms that plague Drakkenheim, the Rat Prince is capable of speech, strategy, and negotiation, though its words are often laced with threats and veiled malice. It commands rats and ratlings with absolute authority, its presence alone enough to drive them into a frenzy or bring them to heel.

Some whisper that the Rat Prince serves a greater power—a dark patron of pestilence—or seeks to crown itself ruler of the city's underworld, both figuratively and literally. Whatever its ambitions, it views all outsiders as trespassers in its domain, to be either driven out, enslaved, or devoured.

entries.name: Study the Foe
entries: Characters proficient in {@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}, {@skill Nature|XPHB}, or {@skill Arcana|XPHB} gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Nature|XPHB}) checks to {@action Study|XPHB} the Rat Prince, learning the following based on their result:

entries.name: (5+) Vermin's Liege.
entries: You know the Rat Prince's creature type and any Resistances or Immunities.

entries.name: (10+) Command of Vermin.
entries: You are aware of its ability to summon and control swarms of rats or ratlings.

entries.name: (15+) Royal Weaknesses.
entries: You learn the Rat Prince's strongest and weakest ability scores and saving throws.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: The Rat Prince rarely fights alone, surrounding itself with loyal swarms and ratling guards. It uses its minions to harry and flank enemies while it strikes from relative safety, often retreating into the shadows if threatened.

If cornered, it fights with feral desperation, lashing out with claws, scepter, and teeth. However, it prefers survival over glory and will flee if the battle turns against it, abandoning even its subjects if necessary.

entries.name: Animus:
entries: Monstrosity or Humanoid (mutated).

entries.name: Fluid:
entries: Monster Blood, Contaminated Ichor.

entries.name: Organs:
entries: Eyes, Heart, Brain.

entries.name: Bones:
entries: Skull, Ribs, Spine.

entries.name: Natural Weapons:
entries: Claws, Teeth.

entries.name: Hide:
entries: Fur, Skin.

condition.name: Addled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma attacks rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Bewildered
entries: You can't cast spells, except for cantrips with a casting time of 1 action.

condition.name: Bleeding
entries: You're losing blood to an open wound.

entries.name: Ongoing Damage
entries: At the end of each of your turns, you lose {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. The number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} lost is indicated by the condition, such as "Bleeding {@dice 2d4}."

entries.name: Regaining Hit Points
entries: The condition ends if you regain any {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Medical Treatment
entries: You or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action and use a healer's kit to staunch the bleeding (no check required), ending the condition.

condition.name: Burning
entries: You're on fire or covered in acid:

entries.name: Ongoing Damage
entries: At the end of each of your turns, you take damage. The damage type and amount are indicated by the condition, such as "Burning ({@dice 4d6} Fire)" or "Burning ({@dice 2d4} Acid)."

entries.name: Ending the Condition
entries: The condition ends if you or another creature within 5 feet of you can spend an action to extinguish the flames or scrape off the acid, or if some other effect douses the flames (such as being submerged in water).

condition.name: Clumsy
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Contamination
entries: While you have Contamination, you experience the following effects.

entries.name: Contamination Levels
entries: This condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain one or more levels of Contamination. You undergo a Monstrous Transformation if your Contamination level reaches 6.

entries.name: Contamination Symptoms
entries: A Contaminated creature suffers the symptoms from its current level as well as all lower levels. Conditions gained from Contamination end when those Contamination levels end. There is no other way to remove conditions caused by symptoms of Contamination.

entries.caption: Contamination Symptoms
rows: Halve the {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} you regain when you expend {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} during a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}
You do not regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Mutations
entries: Each time you gain a Contamination level, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the result is equal to or lower than your current Contamination level, you gain a randomly determined mutation by rolling on the Mutations Table. The effects of the mutation remain while you have Contamination levels. Unless otherwise specified, a creature can't gain the same mutation more than once. If a duplicate result is rolled, the GM chooses a different one or rolls again.

entries.name: Long Rests
entries: Each time you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} while you have 1 or more Contamination levels, roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 1, you gain a Contamination level.

entries.name: Removing Contamination Levels
entries: Only specific magic can remove Contamination levels:

items: The {@spell Purge Contamination|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} spell
{@spell Heal|XPHB} removes all Contamination levels and mutations in addition to its other effects.

Contamination is not a curse, poison, or disease. Spells such as {@spell Lesser Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Protection from Poison|XPHB}, and {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} do not remove Contamination levels.
Being raised from the dead reduces a creature's Contamination level by 1.

entries: When your Contamination level reaches 0, the condition ends, as well as the effects of all mutations.

Skin, hair, fingernails, and toenails lost to mutations regrow normally once Contamination is removed. However, a {@spell Regenerate|XPHB} spell or similar magic is needed to restore any other body parts (such as teeth, limbs, or eyes) lost due to Contamination. Appendages or limbs that develop as a result of mutations wither and fall off when Contamination is removed, and other warped body parts are restored to their original form.

entries.name: Dying with Contamination Levels
entries: If you die while you have one or more Contamination levels, your corpse reanimates as a {@creature Haze Husk|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} 24 hours later. A creature with six or more class levels or hit dice rises as a {@creature Haze Wight|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} instead.

entries.name: Monstrous Transformation!
entries: If you end your turn with six or more Contamination Levels, you permanently transform into a horrific monster controlled by the Game Master.

items: The Game Master chooses the new form, which is most often an Aberration or Monstrosity of some kind such as a {@creature Gibbering Mouther|XMM}, {@creature Delerium Dreg|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}, or {@creature Pyknic Maunder|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
Your game statistics are entirely replaced by those of the chosen monster, including the new form's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice}.
All Contamination levels are removed, though the GM may grant additional traits to the new form similar to any beneficial mutations gained from Contamination Levels.
The Game Master determines what remains of the original creature's personality and memories, if anything. Regardless, the creature falls under the Game Master's control.

entries.name: Reversing the Transformation
entries: A {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell or similar magic can restore a single transformed creature to its previous form, removing all Contamination and restoring the original creature's personality and memories. This is considered a stressful use of the {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell, and thus there is a {@chance 33} chance that the caster will be unable to cast {@spell Wish|XPHB} ever again if they use the spell in this manner.
Note that the means of reversing a monstrous transformation are completely unknown at the outset of the campaign. A Monstrous Transformation is widely regarded as permanent.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: You can move or take an action on your turn, not both. You can't take {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB|Bonus Actions}.

condition.name: Defenseless
entries: Attack rolls against you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

condition.name: Distracted
entries: You can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}.

condition.name: Drakkenheim Madness
entries: A character with Drakkenheim Madness gains one of the following traits:

items: "I wish I didn't have all these useless organs inside me."
"The contamination is a blessing which will transform me into a wondrous creature."
"The monsters are civilians trying to live a peaceful life! We need to protect them!"
"I must wear a flesh-coat made from my slain enemies to gain their strength!"
"My companions died in the ruins. I'm sorry friends, you are merely ghosts haunting me, you aren't real. Stop trying to talk to other people."
"I need to eat everything I can find. It's probably going to be my last meal."
"Drakkenheim is so beautiful at night. I could spend forever wandering the streets by moonlight. We should go tonight! Let's go every night!"
"Don't you fools get it?! If you die in Drakkenheim, you die IN REAL LIFE!!!!"
"A sinister cabal of disembodied hands is plotting against me."
"I must go into the ruins and kill. Rip and tear, until it is done."

condition.name: Enfeebled
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

condition.name: Frozen
entries: You're partially encased in ice:

items: You're {@condition Immobilized|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@condition Defenseless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
You're {@condition Helpless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} against attacks made with a weapon that deals Bludgeoning damage.

You or another creature take an action to break the ice away. To do so, you must succeed on a Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a successful check, the condition ends. The DC is indicated by the condition, such as Frozen (DC 15).
This condition ends on you if you take 20 Bludgeoning or Fire damage.

condition.name: Helpless
entries: Any attack that hits you is a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB}.

items: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} becomes 0, and you can't benefit from any bonuses to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.
If you're flying when you become Immobilized, you fall.

condition.name: Jinxed
entries: Roll the die indicated by the condition, such as "Jinxed {@dice 1d4}" each time you make an attack roll or saving throw. Subtract the value on the die from the result.

items: You're {@condition Dazed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and {@condition Defenseless|MonstersOfDrakkenheim}.
You drop whatever you're holding in your hands.
You must spend an action to draw, stow, or pick up an object.

condition.name: Sickened
entries: You have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Constitution saving throws.

condition.name: Slowed
entries: Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is halved.

condition.name: Staggered
entries: You can't make more than one weapon attack during your turn, regardless of your class features, spells, or magic items.

condition.name: Valor
entries: Add a die to your attack rolls and saving throws. The die rolled is specified by the condition, such as Valor ({@dice 1d4})

condition.name: Weakened
entries: You deal half damage with weapon attacks and spells.

variantrule.name: Epic Action
entries: An Epic Boss takes one Epic Action at the end of each player character's turn. At the game master's discretion, an Epic Boss may take an Epic Action after another non-player character combatant's turn, such as a sidekick or major NPC ally of the player characters.

Therefore, if an Epic Boss were facing five player characters, the boss would take five Epic Actions total during one round of combat, one at the end of each player character's turn. If a player character falls {@condition Unconscious} or dies during the encounter, the Epic Boss continues taking an Epic Action after that character's place in the {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} order.

Some Epic Actions can only be used once per round, and others may have a recharge condition. In addition, certain Epic Actions must be used as the first or last Epic Action the boss takes that round. For example, a {@creature Adult Delerium Dragon|MonstersOfDrakkenheim|Delerium Dragon} may only use its Breath Weapon as the final Epic Action it takes that round.

Epic Actions are not {@action Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}. Game effects which prevent an Epic Boss from taking {@action Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} do not work on Epic Actions, nor do game affects which limit a creature to taking only a movement, {@action Bonus Action|XPHB}, or action on their turn (such as the {@condition Dazed|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} condition).

spell.name: Bacterial Barrage
entries: You attack a creature in range with a quick spreading infection that takes advantage of existing conditions. Make a ranged spell attack against a target, on a hit the infection does {@damage 1d8} necrotic damage to the target. If the target is suffering from the {@condition poisoned} condition or a disease, it instead takes {@damage 1d12} necrotic damage.
The spell's damage increases by one die when you reach 5th level ({@dice 2d8} or {@dice 2d12}), 11th level ({@dice 3d8} or {@dice 3d12}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d8} or {@dice 4d12}).
